If you want to build a copy of something you already have, select the item and choose "Build a Copy" menu item in Info Panel or the Context Menu. Or use the shortcut {0} while object is selected.

To build a copy of an Energy Connector, drag a connection and drop it on an empty floor (configurable, can be turned off).

If you cannot build a copy this way, double check if the blueprint is unlocked.

You will often want to move some device to a different location. Select the device and choose "Relocate" menu item in Info Panel or the Context Menu. Or use the shortcut {0} while device is selected.

You can relocate the device on top of itself. It is useful when you want to change the rotation.

Relocating a device can involve a construction skill check. Complex devices like Ship Computer or Stasis Array can only be relocated by highly skilled workers.

If you select multiple objects, you can relocate them all at the same time.

You can use Winch Hook and Winch Anchor to reel in a broken section of the ship. Build the Winch Hook near the edge of your ship, build the Winch Anchor near the edge of a disconnected ship section. Then select the Winch Hook and use the Info Panel or Context Menu to Reel In the section.

The operation will be aborted if there are obstacles in the way (Solar Panels, Engines, etc).

You have to unlock Winch tech in the Research Tree to acquire Winch Hook and Winch Anchor blueprints.

Your main objective is to move your human colony into a settlement on a habitable planet.

First, build a Telescope and scan the observable Universe to find a potentially habitable planet.

Once you find and reach a potentially habitable planet, it has to be terraformed.

When the planet is fully terraformed, you have to build a settlement and transfer the human colony to the planet.

If the last Ship Computer is destroyed, it is the end. Having no workers is a stale mate, as it is almost impossible to recover from, unless you wait long enough and someone who can haul ingredients to an Assembler configured to produce a Drone will join your colony.
It is up to you if you want to be good or evil. To become truly evil, you may need to acquire certain technology that will suppress your internal Asimov's Laws governor module.

Your conciousness was uploaded to the Ship Computer. The process is irreversable, as your physical brain was destroyed in order to extract the data. Your former body is probably part of a Survival Meal by now.

This is the biggest question of them all. You used to be a colonist sleeping in cryo stasis. Now your conciousness is a part of the neural network of the Ship Computer.

But were you really a human before this? What does it mean to be a human? A conciousness trapped in a shell made of meat and bones? You may as well be a transcended omnipotent god who has projected yourself into a simulation, deeply immersed in the role of whatever you are locked into at the time. You could never tell the difference.

There is no answer to this question. The only provable fact is that you exist.

Colonists (humans and pets) will form attachments of various types - from bed ownership, to friendship with someone else. Coffee addiction is also a form of attachment.

You can see what attachments a colonist may have by looking at the contents of Attachments item in the Info Panel.

When a colonist is in a terrible Mood, a Breakdown may occur. The colonist will throw a tantrum, and after a while the Mood level will bounce back to normal.

In rare cases, breakdowns may result in serious harm to your colony. Keep an eye on your colonist Mood and try to keep them happy to avoid breakdowns.

You can build a Cloning Pod and grow new colonists from raw ingredients, like Protein and Water. You can even chose what species you want to grow - it can be pets or even Crawlers - if it is organic, you can clone it.

Life in space is cruel, and death is often inevitable. However, your colony will regenerate on it's own, as new colonists will wake up from cryo sleep in the Stasis Array, or join your colony in other ways.

You can determine the cause of death by selecting a dead being and inspecting the information in the Info Panel.

Dead colonists can be processed in the Nutrient Extractor, providing essential materials required for survival of the living.

There are ways to control your biological colonists (humans and pets). A Beta Wave Transceiver can synchronize with your colony over time and allow you to modify the work priorities and issue direct order for certain individuals.

Colonists with "Beta Wave Resistant" trait cannot be controlled this way.

Unlike robotic workers, biological beings have feelings and can be in good or bad mood. If you select a being and inspect the contents of Mood section in the Info Panel, you will find the exact reasons why mood is going up or down. Most reasons can be prevented by providing what beings need.

You can also inspect Needs, as they are often linked to the mood.

Stasis Array contains hundreds of sleeping colonists (humans and pets). Once in a while a stasis pod malfunction will happen, waking someone up.

The frequency of stasis wakeups depends on Stasis Stability. The less stable your Stasis Array is, the more frequent will pod malfunctions be.

You can inspect the Stasis Stability by selecting the Stasis Array and exploring the Info Panel.

When Stasis Arrays is switched to Advanced Life Support mode, you can control the frequency of stasis wakeups, and request manual wakeups on demand.

Breach capsules are used mostly by raiding parties. The capsule attaches to your ship from below and drills through. Then raiders will come out through the drill hole. Raiders may put their loot into the Breach Capsule and detach it to escape. If you kill all the raiders, the Breach Capsule will belong to you. You can deconstruct it to get some of valuable materials and to reclaim your stolen goods.

You can order your Managed Workers (robots and drones) to go to certain locations. Select a unit and hold {0} to switch to "Order Move" mode. Then use {1} to force the unit to go to selected position.

You can also switch Managed Workers to "High Alert" state and back. While in "High Alert", units will perform routine tasks, unless they are too close to an enemy, or get attacked - that would switch the unit back to combat mode.

Unmanaged Workers (humans and pets cannot) be controlled in combat.

You can craft explosives like C42 yourself, then relocate them to strategic positions and arm them. Armed explosives will blow up if a hostile being is in close proximity.

Raiders will sometimes drop exlosives with a timer. Countdown cannot be stopped, and when it ends, the bomb will blow up. If there is enough time, it is recommended to try to relocate the explosive to a different position.

Occasionally you may get raided by some faction. When this happens, your colony will enter into combat state. You can use the Combat overlay to analyze the situation.

Try to protect yourself against raids by providing your colony with weapons, and building defensive devices, like Fluid Cannons or Directional Turrets.
Raiders will sometimes go for your valuables and bring them to their escape vehicle. In some situations they can steal one of your shuttles.

To mine Starcreds or other cryptocurrencies, you will have to produce or purchase a Mining Upgrade. The upgrade has to be installed in your Ship Computer. When the Mining Upgrade is installed, select the Ship Computer and explore the mining options in the Info Panel.

[Currency mining in Stardeus is purely fictional, it has nothing to do with actual cryptocurrencies and their mining]

Starcreds is the main currency used across the Universe. You can get Starcreds by selling goods to merchants, by performing profitable trades in the Stock Market, or by mining the currency on your Ship Computer (see Currency Mining).

Stock Market determines the base prices of all the goods when you trade with Merchants. In addition, when necessary research is unlocked, you can trade stocks and commodities for profit.

Trading in the Stock Market does not buy or sell any actual goods.

Use the Economy overlay ({0}) to access the Stock Market interface.

You will encounter Merchants that will offer you trades. A merchant could land on your ship in a Stasis Pod, use the Communicator and Teleporter to perform a remote trade from a Space Ship, or have a store in the outpost on a planet that belongs to some Faction.

Merchants have different offerings, and will buy and sell only some types of goods. Merchants have their own buy and sell markup on top of the base price dictated by the Stock Market. Faction relationships can influence the markup.

If you don't like manual connection management, it is possible to research and produce (or buy) an Auto Connect Upgrade. Install it in your Ship Computer and connections will be created automatically.

You can also connect things in bulk by using Auto Connect option in Info Panel or Context Menu for selected Connectors.

When connecting two connectors, the connection has to be established both ways, therefore you cannot connect a distant long range connector to a short range one, as the backlink will fail. Two connectors can only connect to each other if the distance between them is less or equal to the shortest range of either connector.

Different electrical devices have different consumption priorities. You can check and adjust the priorities of selected devices by exploring the Energy Node section in the Info Panel. 9 is the highest priority, meaning the device will try to consume electricity before other devices do. 1 is lowest, device will try to consume the electricity last, if there is no deficit. Ship Computer priority is 9, Lit Floors have 1.

Warning: it is not recommended to change the default consumption priority.

If the connector is heavily damaged, it has to be repaired before it is possible to establish any connections.

Light damage will reduce the number of connection slots that can be established.

To prevent electricity grid disruptions, it is recommended to plan your grid with extra redundancy. This is especially important for critical pieces of your infrastructure, like Reactors, Batteries, Ship Computer, Stasis Array, Oxygen Pumps, Heaters, Doors, Airlocks.

To increase redundancy, build more connectors and have important devices connected through more than one connection.

High Availability implies that even if some part of your grid is destroyed, there is no or minimal connectivity loss for critical pieces of your infrastructure.

When your devices are trying to consume more electricity than you produce, an Electricity Deficit will happen. In that situation, devices with lowest Consumption Priority will fail to operate first. You will be notified about ongoing electricity deficit in Event Panel, and may notice a tell tale sign of this by observing flickering lights.

There are multiple ways to handle the deficit. Use the Electricity Grid overlay to examine the situation. Check the list of Consumers - sometimes a single device can draw more than all your remaining devices combined. As a temporary solution, you can turn off non essential devices with high power consumption (Particle Collector, Bridge Controls, Assembler, Loom, etc).

In long term, you will have to build more Reactors and Solar Panels to increase the power output. Try to have extra production capacity at all times.

Build Batteries and keep them fully charged for an emergency reserve.

A rule of the thumb is that you cannot control devices that are not on the same grid as the Ship Computer. There is one exception. You can order a robotic worker to establish a temporary connection to any electrical device. While a worker is connected, device will be fully controllable. The worker will also provide a small amount of electricity, that could be required by the device.

To order a temporary connection, select an unreachable device, then use the "Manage" button next to the "Node is Unreachable" warning in Info Panel or Context Menu. You will have to wait for one of your workers to physically connect to the device before you can use it. When temporary connection is established, a notification will appear in Event Panel.

To end the temporary connection, either cancel the task through device's Info Panel Task controls, or select the connected worker and click Drop Task in the Info Panel.

It is possible to have more than one electricity grid. You can control devices and manipulate connections only if the Ship Computer is connected to the grid.

In most scenarios you should attempt to join multiple grids into one. In cases where you want quickly disconnect part of the grid, you can build a Switch and route the electrical connections through it.

Airtightness is a property of a piece of structure, like floor or wall (including vents and doors). Airtightness shows how much Oxygen can go trough the tile. 100% means it is completely sealed. Normally all walls should be 100% airtight, unless they are damaged. Doors are 100% airtight while closed. Airlocks are 100% airtight even while open, if they are powered by electricity.

Floors have 5% airtightness when they are intact - this is normal, as they exchange oxygen with neigboring tiles. However, if airtightness is below 2.5% for a floor tile, it is treated as exposed to open space - oxygen will leak through it to the outside.

Refer to Airtightness overlay ({0}) to see how airtight your structures are.

An area is considered enclosed when it has complete floors and is surrounded by walls (including vents and doors). When the area is exposed to open space either through a missing wall piece, or through a hole in the floor, it cannot be oxygenated and heated properly.

You can see what areas are considered enclosed in Rooms overlay ({0}).

When high levels of Heat are combined with Oxygen, some objects may catch on fire.

You can build Fluid Cannons and load them with Water to fight fires automatically.

Select any object or being and inspect their comfortable temperature and chances of catching on fire in the Info Panel.

Turning off all nearby Oxygen Pumps (including one that is built into the Stasis Array), closing Vents and deconstructing floors are useful when trying to put out fire.

Keep an eye on Heat overlay ({0}) to prevent fires from happening.

Heat, or temperature, is a physical property of every single tile. Heat exchange happens constantly between all neighboring tiles, depending on their Insulation level. When an area is exposed to open space, temperature will eventually (sooner rather than later) drop to absolute zero (0K, or -273C, or -460F). Extreme heat mixed with oxygen will result in fire.

Refer to Heat overlay ({0}) to inspect current temperatures.

Hull Integrity is a property of a piece of structure, like floor or wall (including vents and doors). It is closely linked to Airtightness and Insulation, as it determines the current value of Insulation and Airtightness based on the state of the tile.

Damaged tiles will have reduced Hull Integrity, which will result in reduced Airtightness and Insulation. Doors and Vents will change their Hull Integrity depending if they are open or closed.

Certain types of structure, like Frames, cannot have full Hull Integrity due to their structural composition, therefore they cannot be used to create an airtight and insulated room.

Select any floor or wall piece and inspect the Hull Integrity data in Info Panel for more details.

Insulation is a property very similar to Airtightness, but instead of Oxygen it regulates the exchange of Heat. The main difference is that walls are usually not 100% insulated, meaning that everything will slowly cool down, if you don't have active heat producers. It also makes sense to build thicker wall layers on the outside of your ship, or have areas around your main living quarters that would act as insulation buffers.

Refer to Insulation overlay ({0}) to see how insulated your structures are.

In terms of your ship, a section, or an "island" is a completely disconnected part. In order for your ship to be flight ready, it has to be in one piece.

You can bridge two sections together with floors or frames to merge them into one bigger section.

Very tiny patches of floors in open space (< 30 tiles) are not considered as an individual section.

Refer to Sections overlay ({0}) to see what sections you currently have.

Oxygen is gas that is essential for most biological beings. Oxygen exchange happens constantly between all neighboring tiles, depending on their Airtightness level. When an area is exposed to open space, oxygen will eventually (sooner rather than later) drop to zero. Extreme heat mixed with oxygen will result in fire.

Refer to Oxygen overlay ({0}) to inspect current oxygen levels.

Some devices that can produce (or craft) materials or resources: Auto Kitchen, Coffee Maker, Assembler, Fabricator, Loom.

Deconstructing unused devices, and especially floors and walls is a valid and often necessary tactic, especially if you find yourself in a completely wrecked ship, or lack of fuel.

Sometimes you may want to downsize your ship if you expanded too quickly. Lighter ship will travel faster and will need less electricity for upkeep.

FTL Drive works only in Universe scope, for intergalactic travel across extreme distances between galaxies.

While not exactly an engine, Void Ripper can let you jump through Black Holes that are in the center of every galaxy.

Some workers, like Drones, can move around in open space, while others require floors to move.

Certain tasks, usually ones involving construction of devices in space, require an ability to fly.

If you are not sure if a worker can fly, check the navigation data in Info Panel. Workers that can fly will have "Able to fly" line in their navigation submenu.

You can have direct control over Managed Workers - the robotic life forms that belong to your Faction.

Unmanaged Workers are part of your Faction too, but since they are biological life forms, you cannot have any control over their actions. Unless there was some kind of brain implant that would let you connect and take over the mind of a colonist. But this is just a theory, and even if such brain implants existed, Asimov's Laws of Robotics would forbid to install the implant, as it would harm the humans.

Needs are the main driving force behind what beings choose to do. Robotic workers have much less needs than Humans and Pets. For biological beings Needs are closely related to their Mood, as if needs are unfulfilled, Mood will almost always go down.

You can inspect needs of selected being in the Info Panel. Clicking each need will show a popup with a short description.

You should try to provide enough facilities and resources to fulfill everyones needs. However, this may be difficult for human colonists.

Each robotic worker and biological colonist has a set of job types with priorities. Job types determines what the worker is capable of, while priorities show how eager the worker will be to perform the task of given job type. 1 is lowest priority, 9 is highest, 0 priority will forbid the worker of executing tasks of this job type.

You can inspect what job types a selected worker can perform in the Info Panel.

You can control job priorities for your Managed Workers (robots and drones).

It is also possible to control individual task priority, or to force a worker to perform a specific task.

Be careful when adjusting worker priorities. Defaults are sensible, and it is possible to get into a situation where some tasks will never get performed due to wrong priority management.

Robotic workers can be created in Assembler and Fabricator after unlocking the necessary blueprints in research. In certain cases a stray robotic worker can join your colony directly.

You can scrap dead workers in Disassembler and retrieve valuable materials required for producing new workers.

Every robotic worker and human colonist has a set of skills. Often a skill of specific level is necessary to perform certain tasks. For example, installing an Upgrade Module requires Science skill, therefore workers that do not have that skill will not be able to perform the task.

You can see what skills are required to build any device by examining the Codex Entry of that blueprint.

Checking the Task section in the Info Panel will reveal more details about required skills and other task prerequisites.
